<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_set:
```c
int metal_io_block_set(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       unsigned char value, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	int retlen = len;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_set) {
		(*io->ops.block_set)(
			io, offset, value, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		unsigned int cint = value;
		unsigned int i;

		for (i = 1; i < sizeof(int); i++)
			cint |= ((unsigned int)value << (CHAR_BIT * i));

		for (; len && ((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)); ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
						len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = cint;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags:
for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
					len -= sizeof(int))
explanation: Other control expressions in the function do not need investigation for Rule 14.3 because they are not invariant: - if (!ptr) depends on the runtime result of metal_io_virt and so can vary. - if ((offset + len) > io->size) uses runtime parameters and members of io (offset, len, io->size). - if (io->ops.block_set) depends on the runtime contents of the ops structure pointer. - The call to (*io->ops.block_set)(...) is a function call, not a loop control. - The atomic_thread_fence(...) is not a loop/decision controlling expression. None of these expressions are compile-time constant invariants, so they do not raise Rule 14.3 concerns.
